Scaffold selection, scaffold search, epitope grafting and design optimization are stages of backbone modelling done during rational vaccine design.
children.definition: Model protein backbone conformation.

comment: The model might be of a whole, part or aspect of protein structure. Molecular modelling methods might use sequence-structure alignment, structural templates, molecular dynamics, energy minimisation etc.
children.definition: Build a three-dimensional protein model based on known (for example homologs) structures.
Predict tertiary structure (backbone and side-chain conformation) of protein sequences.

comment: Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).

comment: Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.
children.definition: Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.
Analyse a protein sequence (using methods that are only applicable to protein sequences).

Perform basic (non-analytical) operations on a report or file of sequences (which might include features), such as file concatenation, removal or ordering of sequences, creation of subset or a new file of sequences.
Find (and possibly render) short repetitive subsequences (repeat sequences) in (typically nucleotide) sequences.
Analyse repeat sequence organisation such as periodicity.

comment: Repeat sequences include tandem repeats, inverted or palindromic repeats, DNA microsatellites (Simple Sequence Repeats or SSRs), interspersed repeats, maximal duplications and reverse, complemented and reverse complemented repeats etc. Repeat units can be exact or imperfect, in tandem or dispersed, of specified or unspecified length.
children.definition: Find and/or analyse repeat sequences in (typically nucleotide) sequences.
Identify or predict causes for antibiotic resistance from molecular sequence analysis.

comment: Genomic elements that might be compared include genes, indels, single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), retrotransposons, tandem repeats and so on.
children.definition: Compare the features of two genome sequences.
Compare the feature tables of two or more molecular sequences.
Render and visualise a DNA sequence assembly.

comment: Hydrophobic moment is a peptides hydrophobicity measured for different angles of rotation.
children.definition: Calculate the hydrophobic moment of a peptide sequence and recognize amphiphilicity.

comment: Dot plots are useful when having not too many (e.g. 20) data points for each category. Example: draw a dotplot of sequence similarities identified from word-matching or character comparison.
children.definition: Render a representation of a distribution that consists of group of data points plotted on a simple scale.
Identify and plot third base position variability in a nucleotide sequence.
Visualise, format or render a nucleic acid sequence that is part of (and in context of) a complete genome sequence.
Calculate a density plot (of base composition) for a nucleotide sequence.
Visualise, format or render a molecular sequence or sequences such as a sequence alignment, possibly with sequence features or properties shown.
Classifiication (typically of molecular sequences) by assignment to some taxonomic hierarchy.

comment: Variants are typically classified by their position (intronic, exonic, etc.) in a gene transcript and (for variants in coding exons) by their effect on the protein sequence (synonymous, non-synonymous, frameshifting, etc.)
children.definition: Classify variants based on their potential effect on genes, especially functional effects on the expressed proteins.
Assign molecular sequence(s) to a group or category.

comment: A sequence profile typically represents a sequence alignment. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align molecular sequence(s) to sequence profile(s), or profiles to other profiles.  A profile typically represents a sequence alignment.

comment: This is supposed to give a more biologically meaningful alignment than standard alignments.
children.definition: Align multiple sequences using relative gap costs calculated from neighbors in a supplied phylogenetic tree.
exact_synonyms: Phylogenetic tree-based multiple sequence alignment construction

children.definition: Align molecular sequences using sequence and structural information.

comment: Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align exactly two molecular sequences.

comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment, for example to incorporate sequences into an alignment, or combine several multiple alignments into a single, improved alignment.
children.definition: Align more than two molecular sequences.
Align two or more (tpyically huge) molecular sequences that represent genomes.

comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity.
children.definition: Locally align two or more molecular sequences.

comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire length of the sequences.
children.definition: Globally align two or more molecular sequences.

comment: See also "Read mapping"
children.definition: Align (identify equivalent sites within) molecular sequences.

comment: Motifs and patterns might be conserved or over-represented (occur with improbable frequency).
children.definition: Discover new motifs or conserved patterns in sequences or sequence alignments (de-novo discovery).
Find (scan for) known motifs, patterns and regular expressions in molecular sequence(s).

comment: Look at "Protein feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_3092) and "Nucleic acid feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_0415) in case more specific terms are needed.
children.definition: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in molecular sequences such as key functional sites or regions.
Analyse one or more known molecular sequences.
Analyse a network of protein interactions.
A data mining method typically used for studying biological networks based on pairwise correlations between variables.
Predict a network of gene regulation.
Analyse a known network of gene regulation.

comment: The terms and synyonyms here reflect that for practical intents and purposes, "pathway" and "network" can be treated the same.
children.definition: Model a metabolic network.  This can include 1) reconstruction to break down a metabolic pathways into reactions, enzymes, and other relevant information, and compilation of this into a mathematical model and 2) simulations of metabolism based on the model.
Render (visualise) a network - typically a biological network of some sort.
Predict a network of protein interactions.
Generate, process or analyse a biological network.
Render (visualise) a biological pathway.
Predict a metabolic pathway.

comment: The terms and synyonyms here reflect that for practical intents and purposes, "pathway" and "network" can be treated the same.
children.definition: Model a metabolic network.  This can include 1) reconstruction to break down a metabolic pathways into reactions, enzymes, and other relevant information, and compilation of this into a mathematical model and 2) simulations of metabolism based on the model.
Map an expression profile to known biological pathways, for example, to identify or reconstruct a pathway.
Generate, process or analyse a biological pathway.

comment: Methods typically test for topological similarity between trees using for example a congruence index.
children.definition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to produce a consensus tree.
Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to detect subtrees or supertrees.

comment: Methods typically test for topological similarity between trees using for example a congruence index.
children.definition: Mapping between gene tree nodes and species tree nodes or branches, to analyse and account for possible differences between gene histories and species histories, explaining this in terms of gene-scale events such as duplication, loss, transfer etc.
Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to calculate distances between trees.

comment: For example, to produce a consensus tree, subtrees, supertrees, calculate distances between trees or test topological similarity between trees (e.g. a congruence index) etc.
children.definition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees.
Analyse the shape (topology) of a phylogenetic tree.

comment: Stabilizing/purifying (directional) selection favors a single phenotype and tends to decrease genetic diversity as a population stabilizes on a particular trait, selecting out trait extremes or deleterious mutations. In contrast, balancing selection maintain genetic polymorphisms (or multiple alleles), whereas disruptive (or diversifying) selection favors individuals at both extremes of a trait.
children.definition: Analyse a phylogenetic tree to identify allele frequency distribution and change that is subject to evolutionary pressures (natural selection, genetic drift, mutation and gene flow). Identify type of natural selection (such as stabilizing, balancing or disruptive).
Render or visualise a phylogenetic tree.
Apply bootstrapping or other measures to estimate confidence of a phylogenetic tree.

comment: Ancestral reconstruction is often used to recover possible ancestral character states of ancient, extinct organisms.
children.definition: The extrapolation of empirical characteristics of individuals or populations, backwards in time, to their common ancestors.
The application of phylogenetic and other methods to estimate paleogeographical events such as speciation.

comment: Note that this is somewhat different from simply analysing an existing tree or constructing a completely new one.
children.definition: Reconstructing the inner node labels of a phylogenetic tree from its leafes.

comment: Methods typically test for topological similarity between trees using for example a congruence index.
children.definition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to produce a consensus tree.

comment: Phylogenetic shadowing is a type of footprinting where many closely related species are used.  A phylogenetic 'shadow' represents the additive differences between individual sequences. By masking or 'shadowing' variable positions a conserved sequence is produced with few or none of the variations, which is then compared to the sequences of interest to identify significant regions of conservation.
children.definition: Comparison of a DNA sequence to orthologous sequences in different species and inference of a phylogenetic tree, in order to identify regulatory elements such as transcription factor binding sites (TFBS).
Construct a phylogenetic species tree, for example, from a genome-wide sequence comparison.

comment: Gene trees can provide evidence for gene duplication events, as well as speciation events. Where sequences from different homologs are included in a gene tree, subsequent clustering of the orthologs can demonstrate evolutionary history of the orthologs.
children.definition: Construct a "gene tree" which represents the evolutionary history of the genes included in the study.  This can be used to predict families of genes and gene function based on their position in a phylogenetic tree.
Phylogenetic tree construction from gene frequency data.

Phylogenetic tree construction from polymorphism data including microsatellites, RFLP (restriction fragment length polymorphisms), RAPD (random-amplified polymorphic DNA) and AFLP (amplified fragment length polymorphisms) data.

comment: Methods typically compare multiple molecular sequence and estimate evolutionary distances and relationships to infer gene families or make functional predictions.
children.definition: Phylogenetic tree construction from molecular sequences.
Phylogenetic tree construction from continuous quantitative character data.
exact_synonyms: Phylogenetic tree generation (from continuous quantitative characters)
Phylogenetic tree construction (from continuous quantitative characters)

comment: Subconcepts of this concept reflect different types of data used to generate a tree, and provide an alternate axis for curation.
children.definition: Construct a phylogenetic tree from a specific type of data.

comment: This includes evolutionary parsimony (invariants) methods.
children.definition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing a sequence alignment and searching for the tree with the fewest number of character-state changes from the alignment.
Construct a phylogenetic tree by using artificial-intelligence methods, for example genetic algorithms.

comment: This includes neighbor joining (NJ) clustering method.
children.definition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing (or using precomputed) distances between sequences and searching for the tree with minimal discrepancies between pairwise distances.

comment: Maximum likelihood methods search for a tree that maximizes a likelihood function, i.e. that is most likely given the data and model. Bayesian analysis estimate the probability of tree for branch lengths and topology, typically using a Monte Carlo algorithm.
children.definition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by relating sequence data to a hypothetical tree topology using a model of sequence evolution.
exact_synonyms: Phylogenetic tree construction (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
Phylogenetic tree generation (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
children.text: Phylogenetic inference (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)

children.definition: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing four-taxon trees (4-trees) and searching for the phylogeny that matches most closely.

comment: Subconcepts of this concept reflect different computational methods used to generate a tree, and provide an alternate axis for curation.
children.definition: Construct a phylogenetic tree using a specific method.

comment: Phylogenetic trees are usually constructed from a set of sequences from which an alignment (or data matrix) is calculated.
children.definition: Construct a phylogenetic tree.
Edit a phylogenetic tree.

comment: Phylgenetic modelling is the modelling of trait evolution and prediction of trait values using phylogeny as a basis.
children.definition: Analyse an existing phylogenetic tree or trees, typically to detect features or make predictions.
Label-free quantification by integration of ion current (ion counting).
Calculate number of identified MS2 spectra as approximation of peptide / protein quantity.
Quantification without the use of chemical tags.
Quantification by Selected/multiple Reaction Monitoring workflow (XIC quantitation of precursor / fragment mass pair).
Quantification analysis using the AB SCIEX iTRAQ isobaric labelling workflow, wherein 2-8 reporter ions are measured in MS2 spectra near 114 m/z.

comment: This includes N-15 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using N-15 enriched grown medium or feed) and C-13 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 enriched grown medium or feed).
children.definition: Labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 or N-15 enriched grown medium or feed.
Quantification analysis using chemical labeling by stable isotope dimethylation
Chemical tagging free amino groups of intact proteins with stable isotopes.
Quantification analysis using labeling based on 18O-enriched H2O.
Quantification analysis using the Thermo Fisher tandem mass tag labelling workflow.
Quantification analysis using stable isotope labeling by amino acids in cell culture.
Quantification based on the use of chemical tags.
Technique for determining the amount of proteins in a sample.
Align multiple data sets using information from chromatography and/or peptide identification, from mass spectrometry experiments.
Mass spectra identification of compounds that are produced by living systems. Including polyketides, terpenoids, phenylpropanoids, alkaloids and antibiotics.
Identify peaks in a spectrum from a mass spectrometry, NMR, or some other spectrum-generating experiment.

comment: Deisotoping is commonly done to reduce complexity, and done in conjunction with the charge state deconvolution.
children.definition: The removal of isotope peaks in a spectrum, to represent the fragment ion as one data point.
Identification of protein, for example from one or more peptide identifications by tandem mass spectrometry.
Re-adjust the output of mass spectrometry experiments with shifted ppm values.
Calculate a theoretical mass spectrometry spectra for given sequences.

Statistical estimation of false discovery rate from score distribution for peptide-spectrum-matches, following a peptide database search, and by comparison to search results with a database containing incorrect information.
Peptide database search for identification of known and unknown PTMs looking for mass difference mismatches.
Determination of best matches between MS/MS spectrum and a database of protein or nucleic acid sequences.
Peptide sequence tags are used as piece of information about a peptide obtained by tandem mass spectrometry.
Match experimentally measured mass spectrum to a spectrum in a spectral library or database.
Site localisation of post-translational modifications in peptide or protein mass spectra.
Identification of post-translational modifications (PTMs) of peptides/proteins in mass spectrum.
Analytical process that derives a peptide's amino acid sequence from its tandem mass spectrum (MS/MS) without the assistance of a sequence database.
Determination of peptide sequence from mass spectrum.
Analyse one or more spectra from mass spectrometry (or other) experiments.
Predict a network of gene regulation.

Combine classical quantitative trait loci (QTL) analysis with gene expression profiling, for example, to describe describe cis- and trans-controlling elements for the expression of phenotype associated genes.
exact_synonyms: Gene expression quantitative trait loci profiling

children.definition: Analyse a known network of gene regulation.
The analysis, using proteomics techniques, to identify proteins whose encoding genes are differentially expressed under a given experimental setup.

comment: Differential gene expression analysis is used, for example, to identify which genes are up-regulated (increased expression) or down-regulated (decreased expression) between a group treated with a drug and a control groups.
children.definition: Identify from molecular sequence analysis (typically from analysis of microarray or RNA-seq data) genes whose expression levels are significantly different between two sample groups.

comment: Gene expression profiling generates some sort of gene expression profile, for example from microarray data.
children.definition: The measurement of the activity (expression) of multiple genes in a cell, tissue, sample etc., in order to get an impression of biological function.
The analysis of microRNAs (miRNAs) : short, highly conserved small noncoding RNA molecules that are naturally occurring plant and animal genomes.
Analyse the correlation patterns among features/molecules across across a variety of experiments, samples etc.
Perform cluster analysis of expression data to identify groups with similar expression profiles, for example by clustering.
Comparison of expression profiles.
Analyze time series data from an RNA-seq experiment.
Analyze read counts from RNA-seq experiments.
Analyze data from RNA-seq experiments.
Visualise clustered expression data using a tree diagram.
exact_synonyms: Expression data tree or dendrogram rendering

children.definition: Generate a plot of distances (distance or correlation matrix) between expression values.
Visualise clustered quantitative data as set of different profiles, where each profile is plotted versus different entities or samples on the X-axis.
Visualise gene expression data after hierarchical clustering for representing hierarchical relationships.

comment: The heat map usually uses a coloring scheme to represent expression values. They can show how quantitative measurements were influenced by experimental conditions.
children.definition: Generate a heat map of expression data from e.g. microarray data.
Visualise microarray or other expression data.
Map an expression profile to known biological pathways, for example, to identify or reconstruct a pathway.

comment: "Gene set analysis" (often used interchangeably or in an overlapping sense with "gene-set enrichment analysis") refers to the functional analysis (term enrichment) of a differentially expressed set of genes, rather than all genes analysed.
The Gene Ontology (GO) is typically used, the input is a set of Gene IDs, and the output of the analysis is typically a ranked list of GO concepts, each associated with a p-value.
children.definition: Identify classes of genes or proteins that are over or under-represented in a large set of genes or proteins.  For example analysis of a set of genes corresponding to a gene expression profile, annotated with Gene Ontology (GO) concepts, where eventual over-/under-representation of certain GO concept within the studied set of genes is revealed.

Process (read and/or write) expression data from experiments measuring molecules (e.g. omics data), including analysis of one or more expression profiles, typically to interpret them in functional terms.
Visualise transmembrane proteins, typically the transmembrane regions within a sequence.
Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.

comment: Use this (or child) concept for analysis of transmembrane domains (buried and exposed faces), transmembrane helices, helix topology, orientation, inter-helical contacts, membrane dipping (re-entrant) loops and other secondary structure etc. Methods might use pattern discovery, hidden Markov models, sequence alignment, structural profiles, amino acid property analysis, comparison to known domains or some combination (hybrid methods).
children.definition: Analyse transmembrane protein(s), typically by processing sequence and / or structural data, and write an informative report for example about the protein and its transmembrane domains / regions.

comment: This excludes non-analytical methods that read and write the same basic type of data (for that, see 'Data handling').
children.definition: Apply analytical methods to existing data of a specific type.

comment: Special cases are: a) An operation that consumes no input (has no input arguments). Such operation is either a constant function, or an operation depending only on the underlying state. b) An operation that may modify the underlying state but has no output. c) The singular-case operation with no input or output, that still may modify the underlying state.
children.definition: A function that processes a set of inputs and results in a set of outputs, or associates arguments (inputs) with values (outputs).
Format of a report on exon-intron structure generated by EMBOSS est2genome.
WEGO native format used by the Web Gene Ontology Annotation Plot application.   Tab-delimited format with gene names and others GO IDs (columns) with one annotation record per line.

OrthoXML is designed broadly to allow the storage and comparison of orthology data from any ortholog database. It establishes a structure for describing orthology relationships while still allowing flexibility for database-specific information to be encapsulated in the same format.
Format of a report on a particular locus, gene, gene system or groups of genes.

comment: mirGFF3 is a specialisation of GFF3; produced by small-RNA-Seq analysis workflows, usable and convertible with the miRTop API (https://mirtop.readthedocs.io/en/latest/), and consumable by tools for downstream analysis.
children.definition: mirGFF3 is a common format for microRNA data resulting from small-RNA RNA-Seq workflows.
A "placeholder" concept for formats of annotated RNA data, including e.g. microRNA and RNA-Seq data.
The Zarr format is an implementation of chunked, compressed, N-dimensional arrays for storing data.
Binary format used by MATLAB files to store workspace variables.
Amino acid index format used by the AAindex database.
Data format for an amino acid index.
The Matrix Market matrix (MTX) format stores numerical or pattern matrices in a dense (array format) or sparse (coordinate format) representation.
Format of a matrix of 3D-1D scores (amino acid environment probabilities).
Format of a matrix (array) of numerical values.

comment: BcForms is related to http://edamontology.org/format_3909. (BcForms uses BpForms to describe subunits which are DNA, RNA, or protein polymers.) However, that format isn't the parent of BcForms. BcForms is similarly related to SMILES (http://edamontology.org/data_2301).
children.definition: BcForms is a format for abstractly describing the molecular structure (atoms and bonds) of macromolecular complexes as a collection of subunits and crosslinks. Each subunit can be described with BpForms (http://edamontology.org/format_3909) or SMILES (http://edamontology.org/data_2301). BcForms uses an ontology of crosslinks to abstract the chemical details of crosslinks from the descriptions of complexes (see https://bpforms.org/crosslink.html).
Complete, portable representation of a SYBYL molecule. ASCII file which contains all the information needed to reconstruct a SYBYL molecule.
The format of an entry from the HET group dictionary (HET groups from PDB files).
An MDL Molfile is a file format for holding information about the atoms, bonds, connectivity and coordinates of a molecule.
SDF is one of a family of chemical-data file formats developed by MDL Information Systems; it is intended especially for structural information.
Format of a report on a chemical compound.
CiteXplore 'core' citation format including title, journal, authors and abstract.
XML format for collected entries from biobliographic databases MEDLINE and PubMed.
CiteXplore 'all' citation format includes all known details such as Mesh terms and cross-references.

comment: Bibliographic reference information including citation information is included
children.definition: Format for abstracts of scientific articles from the Medline database.
Format of bibliographic reference as used by the PubMed database.
Format of a bibliographic reference.
AGP is a tabular format for a sequence assembly (a contig, a scaffold/supercontig, or a chromosome).

Graphical Fragment Assembly captures sequence graphs as the product of an assembly, a representation of variation in genomes, splice graphs in genes, or even overlap between reads from long-read sequencing technology.
AFG is a single text-based file assembly format  that holds read and consensus information together
Sequence assembly project file EXP format.
Common Assembly Format (CAF). A sequence assembly format including contigs, base-call qualities, and other metadata.

Graphical Fragment Assembly captures sequence graphs as the product of an assembly, a representation of variation in genomes, splice graphs in genes, or even overlap between reads from long-read sequencing technology.

comment: It is called FASTG, like FASTA, but the G stands for "graph".
children.definition: FASTG is a format for faithfully representing genome assemblies in the face of allelic polymorphism and assembly uncertainty.

Tab-delimited text file format used by Eland - the read-mapping program distributed by Illumina with its sequencing analysis pipeline - which maps short Solexa sequence reads to the human reference genome.
Text format for sequence assembly data.
ACE sequence assembly format including contigs, base-call qualities, and other metadata (version Aug 1998 and onwards).
Format for sequence assembly data.
CopasiML, the native format of COPASI.
Systems Biology Result Markup Language (SBRML), the standard XML format for simulated or calculated results (e.g. trajectories) of systems biology models.
Data format for a report of information derived from a biological pathway or network.
children.text: Biological pathway or network report format

children.definition: Format for sequence positions (feature location) as used in DDBJ/EMBL/GenBank database.

comment: Reflects a UCSC Browser DB table.
children.definition: Cytoband format for chromosome cytobands.
Format used to specify range(s) of sequence positions.
GenePix Results (GPR) text file format developed by Axon Instruments that is used to save GenePix Results data.
Data format for raw microarray data.
Bowtie format for indexed reference genome for "large" genomes.
BAM indexing format
An index of a genome database, indexed for use by the snpeff tool.
Bowtie format for indexed reference genome for "small" genomes.
Index file format used by the samtools package to index TAB-delimited genome position files.
Format of a data index of some type.

A report format for the kinetics of enzyme-catalysed reaction(s) in a format generated by EMBOSS findkm. This includes Michaelis Menten plot, Hanes Woolf plot, Michaelis Menten constant (Km) and maximum velocity (Vmax).
Data format for reports on enzyme kinetics.
Format used for clusters of protein sequences.
Format of affymetrix gene cluster files (hc-genes.txt, hc-chips.txt) from hierarchical clustering.
Format used for clusters of nucleotide sequences.
Format used for clusters of molecular sequences.
A query language (format) for structured database queries.
The FAO/Bioversity/IPGRI Multi-Crop Passport Descriptors (MCPD) is an international standard format for exchange of germplasm information.

comment: BIOM is a recognised standard for the Earth Microbiome Project, and is a project supported by Genomics Standards Consortium. Supported in QIIME, Mothur, MEGAN, etc.
children.definition: The BIological Observation Matrix (BIOM) is a format for representing biological sample by observation contingency tables in broad areas of comparative omics. The primary use of this format is to represent OTU tables and metagenome tables.
Exchange format of the Access to Biological Collections Data (ABCD) Schema; a standard for the access to and exchange of data about specimens and observations (primary biodiversity data).
Data format for biodiversity data.
Microsoft Excel spreadsheet format.
Microsoft Word format.

ObjTables is a toolkit for creating re-usable datasets that are both human and machine-readable, combining the ease of spreadsheets (e.g., Excel workbooks) with the rigor of schemas (classes, their attributes, the type of each attribute, and the possible relationships between instances of classes). ObjTables consists of a format for describing schemas for spreadsheets, numerous data types for science, a syntax for indicating the class and attribute represented by each table and column in a workbook, and software for using schemas to rigorously validate, merge, split, compare, and revision datasets.
MS Excel spreadsheet format consisting of a set of XML documents stored in a ZIP-compressed file.
Portable Document Format

comment: uses the TeX typesetting program format
children.definition: format for the LaTeX document preparation system
Format of documents including word processor, spreadsheet and presentation.
Dirichlet distribution MEME format.
Dirichlet distribution HMMER format.
Data format of a dirichlet distribution.
Data format used by the SQLite database conformant to the Gemini schema.
Variant Call Format (VCF) for sequence variation (indels, polymorphisms, structural variation).
Genome Variation Format (GVF). A GFF3-compatible format with defined header and attribute tags for sequence variation.
Ensembl standard format for variation data.
BCF, the binary version of Variant Call Format (VCF) for sequence variation (indels, polymorphisms, structural variation).
Format of sequence variation annotation.
Abstract format used by MedLine database.
Article format of the PubMed Central database.
Data format for a full-text scientific article.

comment: GROMACS itp files are used also to define position restrictions on the molecule, or to define the force field parameters for a particular ligand.
children.definition: GROMACS itp files (include topology) contain structure topology information, and are tipically included in GROMACS topology files (GROMACS top). Itp files are used to define individual (or multiple) components of a topology as a separate file. This is particularly useful if there is a molecule that is used frequently, and also reduces the size of the system topology file, splitting it in different parts.
AMBER frcmod (Force field Modification) is a file format to store any modification to the standard force field needed for a particular molecule to be properly represented in the simulation.
AMBER Object File Format library files (OFF library files) store residue libraries (forcefield residue parameters).

comment: Many different file formats exist describing force field parameters. Tipically, each MD package or simulation software works with their own implementation (e.g. GROMACS itp, CHARMM rtf, AMBER off / frcmod).
children.definition: Format of force field parameter files, which store the set of parameters (charges, masses, radii, bond lengths, bond dihedrals, etc.) that are essential for the proper description and simulation of a molecular system.

comment: For SOLiD data, the sequence is in color space, except the first position. The quality values are those of the Sanger format.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for SOLiD data.

comment: Starting in Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8, the Phred scores 0 to 2 have a slightly different meaning. The values 0 and 1 are no longer used and the value 2, encoded by ASCII 66 "B", is used also at the end of reads as a Read Segment Quality Control Indicator.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8.

comment: Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format can encode a Solexa/Illumina quality score from -5 to 62 using ASCII 59 to 126 (although in raw read data Solexa scores from -5 to 40 only are expected)
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format.
FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from 454 sequencers.

comment: Phred quality scores  are defined as a property which is logarithmically related to the base-calling error probabilities.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences).
Textual report format for sequence quality for reports from sequencing machines.
Format of PHYLIP cliques data.
Format of phylogenetic cliques data.
PHYLIP file format for phylogenetics character frequency data.
PHYLIP file format for continuous quantitative character data.
Format of phylogenetic continuous quantitative character data.
Format of phylogenetic invariants data.
Format of PHYLIP discrete states data.
Format of phylogenetic discrete states data.
Format of raw (unplotted) phylogenetic data.

comment: It is basically a translation of the ASCII atom coordinate format to binary code. The only additional information stored is a magic number that identifies the BinPos format and the number of atoms per snapshot. The remainder is the chain of coordinates binary encoded. A drawback of this format is its architecture dependency. Integers and floats codification depends on the architecture, thus it needs to be converted if working in different platforms (little endian, big endian).
children.definition: Scripps Research Institute BinPos format is a binary formatted file to store atom coordinates.

comment: Fully architecture-independent format, regarding both endianness and the ability to mix single/double precision trajectories and I/O libraries. Self-sufficient, it should not require any other files for reading, and all the data should be contained in a single file for easy transport. Temporal compression of data, improving the compression rate of the previous XTC format. Possibility to store meta-data with information about the simulation. Direct access to a particular frame. Efficient parallel I/O.
children.definition: Trajectory Next Generation (TNG) is a format for storage of molecular simulation data. It is designed and implemented by the GROMACS development group, and it is called to be the substitute of the XTC format.

comment: The compression is made projecting the Cartesian snapshots collected along the trajectory into an orthogonal space defined by the most relevant eigenvectors obtained by diagonalization of the covariance matrix (PCA). In the compression/decompression process, part of the original information is lost, depending on the final number of eigenvectors chosen. However, with a reasonable choice of the set of eigenvectors the compression typically reduces the trajectory file to less than one tenth of their original size with very acceptable loss of information. Compression with PCAZip can only be applied to unsolvated structures.
children.definition: PCAZip format is a binary compressed file to store atom coordinates based on Essential Dynamics (ED) and Principal Component Analysis (PCA).

comment: HDF is currently supported by many commercial and non-commercial software platforms such as Java, MATLAB/Scilab, Octave, Python and R.
children.definition: HDF is the name of a set of file formats and libraries designed to store and organize large amounts of numerical data, originally developed at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois.

comment: XTC uses the External Data Representation (xdr) routines for writing and reading data which were created for the Unix Network File System (NFS). XTC files use a reduced precision (lossy) algorithm which works multiplying the coordinates by a scaling factor (typically 1000), so converting them to pm (GROMACS standard distance unit is nm). This allows an integer rounding of the values. Several other tricks are performed, such as making use of atom proximity information: atoms close in sequence are usually close in space (e.g. water molecules). That makes XTC format the most efficient in terms of disk usage, in most cases reducing by a factor of 2 the size of any other binary trajectory format.
children.definition: Portable binary format for trajectories produced by GROMACS package.

The Loom file format is based on HDF5, a standard for storing large numerical datasets. The Loom format is designed to efficiently hold large omics datasets. Typically, such data takes the form of a large matrix of numbers, along with metadata for the rows and columns.

comment: HDF5 is the new version, according to the HDF group, a completely different technology (https://support.hdfgroup.org/products/hdf4/ compared to HDF.

An HDF5 file appears to the user as a directed graph. The nodes of this graph are the higher-level HDF5 objects that are exposed by the HDF5 APIs: Groups, Datasets, Named datatypes. Currently supported by the Python MDTraj package.
children.definition: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data, based on Hierarchical Data Format (HDF).

Format used by netCDF software  library for writing and reading chromatography-MS data files.  Also used to store trajectory atom coordinates information, such as the ones obtained by Molecular Dynamics simulations.
Binary file format to store trajectory information for a 3D structure .
Format of trr files that contain the trajectory of a simulation experiment used by GROMACS.
AMBER coordinate/restart file with 6 coordinates per line and decimal format F12.7 (fixed point notation with field width 12 and 7 decimal places)
AMBER trajectory (also called mdcrd), with 10 coordinates per line and format F8.3 (fixed point notation with field width 8 and 3 decimal places).

comment: XYZ files are structured in this way:  First line contains the number of atoms in the file.  Second line contains a title, comment, or filename. Remaining lines contain atom information. Each line starts with the element symbol, followed by x, y and z coordinates in angstroms separated by whitespace. Multiple molecules or frames can be contained within one file, so it supports trajectory storage. XYZ files can be directly represented by a molecular viewer, as they contain all the basic information needed to build the 3D model.
children.definition: The XYZ chemical file format is widely supported by many programs, although many slightly different XYZ file formats coexist (Tinker XYZ, UniChem XYZ, etc.). Basic information stored for each atom in the system are x, y and z coordinates and atom element/atomic number.
Textual file format to store trajectory information for a 3D structure .

comment: Formats differ on what they are able to store (coordinates, velocities, topologies) and how they are storing it (raw, compressed, textual, binary).
children.definition: File format to store trajectory information for a 3D structure .
Report format on PCR primers and hybridisation oligos as generated by Whitehead primer3 program.
Format of a report on PCR primers or hybridisation oligos in a nucleic acid sequence.

BioXSD-schema-based XML format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, Web services, and object-oriented programming.
. proBAM is an adaptation of BAM (format_2572), which was extended to meet specific requirements entailed by proteomics data.
A format of raw sequence read data from an Applied Biosystems sequencing machine.

comment: The format supports short and long reads (up to 128Mbp) produced by different sequencing platforms and is used to hold mapped data within the GATK and across the Broad Institute, the Sanger Centre, and throughout the 1000 Genomes project.
children.definition: Sequence Alignment/Map (SAM) format for alignment of nucleotide sequences (e.g. sequencing reads) to (a) reference sequence(s). May contain base-call and alignment qualities and other data.
Sequence Read Format (SRF) of sequence trace data. Supports submission to the NCBI Short Read Archive.
Standard flowgram format (SFF) is a binary file format used to encode results of pyrosequencing from the 454 Life Sciences platform for high-throughput sequencing.

comment: AB1 uses the generic binary Applied Biosystems, Inc. Format (ABIF).
children.definition: AB1 binary format of raw DNA sequence reads (output of Applied Biosystems' sequencing analysis software). Contains an electropherogram and the DNA base sequence.
ZTR format for storing chromatogram data from DNA sequencing instruments.

BAM format, the binary, BGZF-formatted compressed version of SAM format for alignment of nucleotide sequences (e.g. sequencing reads) to (a) reference sequence(s). May contain base-call and alignment qualities and other data.
FASTQ short read format with phred quality.

comment: Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format can encode a Solexa/Illumina quality score from -5 to 62 using ASCII 59 to 126 (although in raw read data Solexa scores from -5 to 40 only are expected)
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format.
FASTQ Solexa/Illumina 1.0 short read format.

comment: For SOLiD data, the sequence is in color space, except the first position. The quality values are those of the Sanger format.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for SOLiD data.

comment: Starting in Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8, the Phred scores 0 to 2 have a slightly different meaning. The values 0 and 1 are no longer used and the value 2, encoded by ASCII 66 "B", is used also at the end of reads as a Read Segment Quality Control Indicator.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8.

comment: Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format can encode a Solexa/Illumina quality score from -5 to 62 using ASCII 59 to 126 (although in raw read data Solexa scores from -5 to 40 only are expected)
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format.
FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from 454 sequencers.

comment: Starting in Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8, the Phred scores 0 to 2 have a slightly different meaning. The values 0 and 1 are no longer used and the value 2, encoded by ASCII 66 "B", is used also at the end of reads as a Read Segment Quality Control Indicator.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8.

There no length restrictions on the ID, but whitespaces aren't allowed in the sequence ID/Name because one space separates the longest ID and the beginning of the sequence. Sequences IDs must be padded to the longest ID length.

There no length restrictions on the ID, but whitespaces aren't allowed in the sequence ID/Name because one space separates the longest ID and the beginning of the sequence. BioJSON is a BioXSD-schema-based JSON format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web applications and APIs, and object-oriented programming.
Data format for a molecular sequence record.
A format of text annotation using the linked-data Open Annotation Data Model, serialised typically in RDF or JSON-LD.
JSON-LD, or JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data, is a method of encoding Linked Data using JSON.
exact_synonyms: JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data

children.definition: A format of text annotation using the linked-data Open Annotation Data Model, serialised typically in RDF or JSON-LD.

comment: RDF/XML is a serialisation syntax for OWL DL, but not for OWL Full.
children.definition: Resource Description Framework (RDF) XML format.

comment: The SPARQL Query Language incorporates a very similar syntax.
children.definition: The Terse RDF Triple Language (Turtle) is a human-friendly serialisation format for RDF (Resource Description Framework) graphs.
A shorthand non-XML serialisation of Resource Description Framework model, designed with human-readability in mind.
OWL ontology XML serialisation format.

comment: This format was influenced by the OWL Abstract Syntax and the DL style syntax.
children.definition: A syntax for writing OWL class expressions.
A human-readable encoding for the Web Ontology Language (OWL).
A serialisation format conforming to the Web Ontology Language (OWL) model.
A format of text annotation using the linked-data Open Annotation Data Model, serialised typically in RDF or JSON-LD.

children.definition: A plain text serialisation format for RDF (Resource Description Framework) graphs, and a subset of the Turtle (Terse RDF Triple Language) format.
UniProtKB RDF sequence features format is an RDF format available for downloading UniProt entries (in RDF/XML).

comment: N-Quads should not be confused with N-Triples which does not contain graph information.
children.definition: N-Quads is a line-based, plain text format for encoding an RDF dataset. It includes information about the graph each triple belongs to.
A serialisation format conforming to the Resource Description Framework (RDF) model.
A linked data format enables publishing structured data as linked data (Linked Data), so that the data can be interlinked and become more useful through semantic queries.

comment: Pcons ranks protein models by assessing their quality based on the occurrence of recurring common three-dimensional structural patterns. Pcons returns a score reflecting the overall global quality and a score for each individual residue in the protein reflecting the local residue quality.
children.definition: Format of output of the Pcons Model Quality Assessment Program (MQAP).

comment: ProQ is a neural network-based predictor that predicts the quality of a protein model based on the number of structural features.
children.definition: Format of output of the ProQ protein model quality predictor.
Format of a report on the quality of a protein three-dimensional model.
CellML, the format for mathematical models of biological and other networks.
BioPAX is an exchange format for pathway data, with its data model defined in OWL.
SBtab is a tabular format for biochemical network models.
CopasiML, the native format of COPASI.
SIF (simple interaction file) Format - a network/pathway format used for instance in cytoscape.
A model description language for computational neuroscience.
SBGN-ML is an XML format for Systems Biology Graphical Notation (SBGN) diagrams of biological pathways or networks.
Systems Biology Markup Language (SBML), the standard XML format for models of biological processes such as for example metabolism, cell signaling, and gene regulation.
GML (Graph Modeling Language) is a text file format supporting network data with a very easy syntax. It is used by Graphlet, Pajek, yEd, LEDA and NetworkX.

comment: An OMEX file is a ZIP container that includes a manifest file, listing the content of the archive, an optional metadata file adding information about the archive and its content, and the files describing the model. OMEX is one of the standardised formats within COMBINE (Computational Modeling in Biology Network).
children.definition: Open Modeling EXchange format (OMEX) is a ZIPped format for encapsulating all information necessary for a modeling and simulation project in systems biology.
Graphical Pathway Markup Language (GPML) is an XML format used for exchanging biological pathways.
BioNetGen is a format for the specification and simulation of rule-based models of biochemical systems, including signal transduction, metabolic, and genetic regulatory networks.
The KEGG Markup Language (KGML) is an exchange format of the KEGG pathway maps, which is converted from internally used KGML+ (KGML+SVG) format.
Default XML format of VisANT, containing all the network information.
Biological Connection Markup Language (BCML) is an XML format for biological pathways.
Data format for a biological pathway or network.

comment: The DSSP database is built using the DSSP application which defines secondary structure, geometrical features and solvent exposure of proteins, given atomic coordinates in PDB format.
children.definition: Format of an entry from the DSSP database (Dictionary of Secondary Structure in Proteins).
Entry format of the HSSP database (Homology-derived Secondary Structure in Proteins).
Format for secondary structure (predicted or real) of a protein molecule.

comment: This includes (typically) score data, alignment data and a histogram (of observed and expected distribution of E values.)
children.definition: Format of results of a sequence database search using FASTA.

comment: The hits are relatives to a SCOP or CATH family and are found from a search of a sequence database.
children.definition: Format of EMBASSY domain hits file (DHF) of hits (sequences) with domain classification information.
Format of results of a sequence database search using some variant of Smith Waterman.

comment: The hits are putative ligand-binding sequences and are found from a search of a sequence database.
children.definition: Format of EMBASSY ligand hits file (LHF) of database hits (sequences) with ligand classification information.
Format of results of a sequence database search using some variant of MSPCrunch.
EBI Application Result XML is a format returned by sequence similarity search Web services at EBI.

comment: The table presents matches between query proteins (rows) and signature methods (columns) for this entry. Alternatively the sequence(s) might be from from the InterPro entry itself. The match position in the protein sequence and match status (true positive, false positive etc) are indicated.
children.definition: Format of results of a search of the InterPro database showing matches between protein sequence(s) and signatures for an InterPro entry.

comment: The report includes a classification of regions in a query protein sequence which are assigned to a known InterPro protein family or group.
children.definition: Format of results of a search of the InterPro database showing matches of query protein sequence(s) to InterPro entries.
Results format for searches of the InterPro database.
XML format as produced by the NCBI Blast package
XML format as produced by the NCBI Blast package v2.

comment: This includes score data, alignment data and summary table.
children.definition: Format of results of a sequence database search using some variant of BLAST.
Format of a report on sequence hits and associated data from searching a sequence database.
Format of a report from the HMMER package on the emission and transition counts of a hidden Markov model.
Data format for the emission and transition counts of a hidden Markov model.
children.text: HMM emission and transition counts format

comment: Differ from .dta only in subtleties of the header line format and content and support the added feature of being able to.
children.definition: Spectral data file similar to dta.

comment: This format corresponds to an SQLite database, and you can look into the files with e.g. SQLiteStudio3. There are also some readers (http://doi.org/10.1021/pr2005154) and converters (http://doi.org/10.1016/j.jprot.2015.06.015) for this format available, which re-engineered the database schema, but there is no official DB schema specification of Thermo Scientific for the format.
children.definition: Proprietary mass-spectrometry format of Thermo Scientific's ProteomeDiscoverer software.
Format supported by the Tide tool for identifying peptides from tandem mass spectra.

comment: The focus of qcML is towards mass spectrometry based proteomics, but the format is suitable for metabolomics and sequencing as well.
children.definition: qcML is an XML format for quality-related data of mass spectrometry and other high-throughput measurements.

comment: imzML data is recorded in 2 files: '.imzXML' is a metadata XML file based on mzML by HUPO-PSI, and '.ibd' is a binary file containing the mass spectra.
children.definition: ibd is a data format for mass spectrometry imaging data.
Common file format for proteomics mass spectrometric data developed at the Seattle Proteome Center/Institute for Systems Biology.
Format of peak list files from Andromeda search engine (MaxQuant) that consist of arbitrarily many spectra.

mzQuantML is the format for quantitation values associated with peptides, proteins and small molecules from mass spectra, standardised by HUPO PSI PI. It can be used for outputs of quantitation software for proteomics.
Mass spectrum file format from QSTAR and QTRAP instruments (ABI/Sciex).
XML file format for files containing information about peptide identifications from mass spectrometry data analysis carried out with OpenMS.
mzTab is a tab-delimited format for mass spectrometry-based proteomics and metabolomics results.

Open data format for the storage, exchange, and processing of peptide sequence assignments of MS/MS scans, intended to provide a common data output format for many different MS/MS search engines and subsequent peptide-level analyses.
"Raw" result file from SEQUEST database search.
"Raw" result file from Mascot database search.
Output format used by X! series search engines that is based on the XML language BIOML.
PRIDE XML is an XML format for mass spectra, peptide and protein identifications, and metadata about a corresponding measurement, sample, experiment.

comment: Each file contains one header line for the known or assumed charge and the mass of the precursor peptide ion, calculated from the measured *m*/*z* and the charge. This one line was then followed by all the *m*/*z*, intensity pairs that represent the spectrum.
children.definition: Spectral data format file where each spectrum is written to a separate file.

comment: No human-consumable information about this format is available (see http://tools.proteomecenter.org/wiki/index.php?title=Formats:protXML).
children.definition: A format for storage, exchange, and processing of protein identifications created from ms/ms-derived peptide sequence data.

comment: imzML data are recorded in 2 files: '.imzXML' is a metadata XML file based on mzML by HUPO-PSI, and '.ibd' is a binary file containing the mass spectra. This entry is for the metadata XML file
children.definition: imzML metadata is a data format for mass spectrometry imaging metadata.
Now deprecated data format of the HUPO Proteomics Standards Initiative.  Replaced by mzML (format_3244).

comment: BcForms is related to http://edamontology.org/format_3909. (BcForms uses BpForms to describe subunits which are DNA, RNA, or protein polymers.) However, that format isn't the parent of BcForms. BcForms is similarly related to SMILES (http://edamontology.org/data_2301).
children.definition: BcForms is a format for abstractly describing the molecular structure (atoms and bonds) of macromolecular complexes as a collection of subunits and crosslinks. Each subunit can be described with BpForms (http://edamontology.org/format_3909) or SMILES (http://edamontology.org/data_2301). BcForms uses an ontology of crosslinks to abstract the chemical details of crosslinks from the descriptions of complexes (see https://bpforms.org/crosslink.html).

comment: NMReData is a text based data standard for processed NMR data. It is relying on SDF molecule data and allows to store assignments of NMR peaks to molecule features. The NMR-extracted data (or "NMReDATA") includes: Chemical shift,scalar coupling, 2D correlation, assignment, etc. Find more in the paper at D. Jeannerat, Magn. Reson. in Chem., 2017, 55, 7-14.
children.definition: MReData is a text based data standard for processed NMR data. It is relying on SDF molecule data and allows to store assignments of NMR peaks to molecule features.  The NMR-extracted data (or "NMReDATA") includes: Chemical shift,scalar coupling, 2D correlation, assignment, etc.
nmrML is an MSI supported XML-based open access format for metabolomics NMR raw and processed spectral data. It is accompanies by an nmrCV (controlled vocabulary) to allow ontology-based annotations.
Data format for raw data from a nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy experiment.
exact_synonyms: Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy data format

children.definition: The PED file describes individuals and genetic data and is used by the Plink package.
The MAP file describes SNPs and is used by the Plink package.
The PED/MAP file describes data used by the Plink package.
Data format for a metadata on an individual and their genetic data.

comment: GROMACS itp files are used also to define position restrictions on the molecule, or to define the force field parameters for a particular ligand.
children.definition: GROMACS itp files (include topology) contain structure topology information, and are tipically included in GROMACS topology files (GROMACS top). Itp files are used to define individual (or multiple) components of a topology as a separate file. This is particularly useful if there is a molecule that is used frequently, and also reduces the size of the system topology file, splitting it in different parts.

comment: The high similarity in the functional form of the two potential energy functions used by AMBER and CHARMM force-fields gives rise to the possible use of one force-field within the other MD engine. Therefore, the conversion of PSF files to AMBER Prmtop format is possible with the use of AMBER chamber (CHARMM - AMBER) program.
children.definition: X-Plor Protein Structure Files (PSF) are structure topology files used by NAMD and CHARMM molecular simulations programs. PSF files contain six main sections of interest: atoms, bonds, angles, dihedrals, improper dihedrals (force terms used to maintain planarity) and cross-terms.

comment: version 7 is written to distinguish it from old versions of AMBER Prmtop. Similarly to HDF5, it is a completely different format, according to AMBER group: a drastic change to the file format occurred with the 2004 release of Amber 7 (http://ambermd.org/prmtop.pdf)

It can be modified manually, but as the size of the system increases, the hand-editing becomes increasingly complex. AMBER Parameter-Topology file format is used extensively by the AMBER software suite and is referred to as the Prmtop file for short.
children.definition: AMBER Prmtop file (version 7) is a structure topology text file divided in several sections designed to be parsed easily using simple Fortran code. Each section contains particular topology information, such as atom name, charge, mass, angles, dihedrals, etc.

comment: There is currently no tool available for conversion between GROMACS topology format and other formats, due to the internal differences in both approaches. There is, however, a method to convert small molecules parameterized with AMBER force-field into GROMACS format, allowing simulations of these systems with GROMACS MD package.
children.definition: Format of CHARMM Residue Topology Files (RTF), which define groups by including the atoms, the properties of the group, and bond and charge information.

comment: There is currently no tool available for conversion between GROMACS topology format and other formats, due to the internal differences in both approaches. There is, however, a method to convert small molecules parameterized with AMBER force-field into GROMACS format, allowing simulations of these systems with GROMACS MD package.
children.definition: GROMACS MD package top textual files define an entire structure system topology, either directly, or by including itp files.

comment: Many different file formats exist describing structural molecular topology. Tipically, each MD package or simulation software works with their own implementation (e.g. GROMACS top, CHARMM psf, AMBER prmtop).
children.definition: Format of topology files; containing the static information of a structure molecular system that is needed for a molecular simulation.
